page.title: 07The Henley Education Charity
page.content: In 1604 only rich people could afford to send their sons to school. Dame Periam wanted poor boys to have education too,so she started a school for them. Her money provided a building and paid the headmasters wages. Now that the goverment provides buildings and pay teachers, Dame Periam's money can be used for other things, like books and computers. Some other people, William Gravett and Alex Knapp, also gave money for education and all their schools became the Henley Grammar school about 1890. There are 11 people on the committee. They gather six evenings a year to split the money up. Mrs. Day wants to stay on the committee as long as they want her to. Schools and parents of individual children can apply for grants to help them with outings and equipment.
